courses.name: Art and Ideas

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Ideas

courses.name: Art and Ideas

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: January 11, 2018

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: January 11, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Ideas

courses.name: Prehistoric Aegean and East Mediterranean Art and Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the Aegean region and the east Mediterranean to 1000BC.
cmCourseInfo.title: Prehistoric Aegean and East Mediterranean Art and Archaeology

courses.name: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the civilizations of Greece and Rome.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology

courses.name: Later Medieval Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of Western Europe and the Byzantine East from the eleventh until the fifteenth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Later Medieval Art and Architecture

courses.name: Renaissance Art and Architecture (formerly FAH274H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective survey of the major art centres and types of artistic and architectural production in Italy and northern Europe, from the early fifteenth century to the mid-sixteenth. Themes include the relations--artistic, economic and ideological--between northern and southern Europe during this period, the changing role of art in religious life, the emergence of secular themes, and the legacies left by Renaissance art to modern life and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Renaissance Art and Architecture (formerly FAH274H1)

courses.name: Art Since 1900

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the consolidation of Modernist tendencies in Europe to the mid 20th century and to the many contemporary responses to these achievements. Individual artists, including Picasso, Matisse, Duchamp, and Matthew Barney are considered in their relationship to various art movements and the theories that supported them, including Expressionism; Abstraction and Constructivism; Dada and Surrealism; Neue Sachlichkeit; Abstract Expressionism; Pop; Conceptual Art; Earth Art; Feminist Art; Postmodernism; New Media Art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art Since 1900

courses.name: Canadian Painting 1665-1960 (formerly FAH286H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory survey of the history of painting in Canada from the 17th to the 20th century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Painting 1665-1960 (formerly FAH286H1)

courses.name: Art and Visual Experience in Modern and Contemporary East Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of East Asia (China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, Mongolia and Tibet) and its diaspora in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Visual Experience in Modern and Contemporary East Asia

courses.name: Monuments of the Islamic World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the architecture of the Islamic world from the 7th - 12th centuries through the lens of its major monuments throughout the central Islamic lands, North Africa and Spain. Through an emphasis upon the Umayyad, Abbasid, Fatimid and Seljuk periods, the course explores the range of cultural, political, social and religious aspects related to the development of the built environment. It also considers the impact of Islam's encounter with late antiquity and aims to position the rise of Islamic architecture within the context of this encounter. Additionally, the architecture is contextualized through a study of the urban history of select early and medieval Islamic cities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Monuments of the Islamic World

courses.name: Architecture: Rituals and Monuments

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of architecture from pre-history to the start of modernism, with attention given to the ways in which architecture shapes human experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Architecture: Rituals and Monuments

courses.name: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the buildings, issues and ideas from Neoclassicism to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

courses.name: Emergence of Greek Civilisation

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Session and Time Changed: June 27, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates the material culture, art and architecture of the Aegean civilizations from the Neolithic through to the building of the palaces of Crete around 2000BC.
cmCourseInfo.title: Emergence of Greek Civilisation

courses.name: Greek Sculpture

cmCourseInfo.description: The course provides a thorough examination of ancient Greek sculpture from 7th - 1st century BCE, which in many ways defined the canon of western art that was to follow. Classic issues of style, dating, and technique are complemented by putting them into the contexts of cultural history, religion and socio-politics. While the course is a traditional monument-based survey of major sculptural works from the ancient Greek world, several important issues are also addressed, pertaining both to contemporary society and the study of other areas of art history. These include but are not limited to: gender, social class, colonialism, notion of the artist, originality, and aesthetic theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Sculpture

courses.name: Greek Myth in Ancient Art

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introduction to Greek mythology and its uses (and abuses) by the Greeks and Romans through the art of antiquity. Students will learn about gods and goddesses, heroes and heroines, their attributes and stories which constituted the subjects of (not only) ancient art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Myth in Ancient Art

courses.name: Gothic Cathedral (formerly FAH369H1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: July 31, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the Gothic cathedral from its origins in Paris in the 1130s through its development and elaboration in France, England and Italy. This course also considers monumental decorations in painted glass, wall painting, tapestry and portal sculpture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gothic Cathedral (formerly FAH369H1)

courses.name: Venetian Renaissance Art and Architecture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room changed: November 23, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Form and meaning, theory and practice of painting and architecture in Venice, ca. 1450-ca. 1600. Social, political and cultural contexts of making and viewing art, including works by Giorgione, Titian, Veronese, Tintoretto and Palladio.
cmCourseInfo.title: Venetian Renaissance Art and Architecture

courses.name: Rembrandt, Rubens and their Age (formerly FAH277H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the art of Rembrandt and Rubens in the context of Netherlandish painting of the seventeenth century. Lectures will treat the approaches of these two artists to biblical and mythological subjects, landscape, portraiture, and their involvement in contemporary politics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rembrandt, Rubens and their Age (formerly FAH277H1)

courses.name: Abstraction in Twentieth-Century Art (formerly FAH387H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The origins, development, and critical issues pertaining to abstract or non-figurative modes of art as manifested in painting, sculpture and other selected media upt to the present time. Movements include European abstract art before World War II as well as post-war developments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Abstraction in Twentieth-Century Art (formerly FAH387H1)

courses.name: 19th Century Photography

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the major artists, movements, and debates in photography in Europe and North America, from its prehistory to the turn of the century. Issues considered include the relationship of social class to aesthetics, the role of illusion, the rise of mass reproduction.
cmCourseInfo.title: 19th Century Photography

courses.name: Recent and Contemporary Canadian Art (formerly FAH386H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the visual arts in Canada from the 1960s to the present. A large and diverse range of media, practices, artists, and theoretical contexts will be examined. Emphasis is placed on work that can be seen in the original.
cmCourseInfo.title: Recent and Contemporary Canadian Art (formerly FAH386H1)

courses.name: European Renaissance Architecture (formerly FAH324H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Architecture and architectural theory ca. 1400 ca. 1600.
cmCourseInfo.title: European Renaissance Architecture (formerly FAH324H1)

courses.name: Understanding Dionysos: The God of Wine, Theatre and the Afterlife

cmCourseInfo.description: The Greek god Dionysos presents a multifaceted entry point into exploring Ancient Greek art, culture, religion and history. This course is a comprehensive exploration of the figure of Dionysos, from his obscure pre-historic beginnings of foreign origin, to his transformation into other post-classical entities, spanning Christianity to Buddhism. A substantial part of the course deals with his representations in Greek art, and the god's relationship to the Greeks as the governing figure of many important facets of their lives: drinking practices, sexuality, the performative arts, and the transition into the afterlife through the notion of eternal bliss. The course reading draws on art historical literature, as well as primary sources, and theoretical texts regarding religion and cultural practices.
cmCourseInfo.title: Understanding Dionysos: The God of Wine, Theatre and the Afterlife
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FAH207H1 / FAH310H1 / FAH311H1 / FAH312H1 / FAH313H1 / CLA204H1 / FAH232H1

courses.name: The Palaces of Minoan Crete

cmCourseInfo.description: Around 2000 BC, the island of Crete sees the emergence of what are arguably the earliest towns and states in European prehistory. At the heart of this new social order are the so-called palaces, massive architectural complexes usually interpreted as seats of administrative and political authority. However, fresh discoveries over the past two decades, coupled recently with radical new interpretations, require a fundamental rethinking of the nature of the palaces and their role in Minoan society. This course will provide students with an active opportunity to learn about the latest developments in Minoan art, architecture, and archaeology.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Palaces of Minoan Crete

courses.name: Leonardo and His Legacy in Renaissance Italy

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room changed: September 15, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar examines major critical developments in the interpretation of High Renaissance art in Italy by looking at key works produced by Leonardo, his contemporaries, and followers (1470-1530).
cmCourseInfo.title: Leonardo and His Legacy in Renaissance Italy

courses.name: Issues in Canadian Art, ca. 1900-1940 (formerly FAH415H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused, thematic examinations of the visual arts in Canada in the first half of the twentieth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Canadian Art, ca. 1900-1940 (formerly FAH415H1)

courses.name: Issues in Recent Canadian Art (formerly FAH416H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused, thematic examinations of the visual arts in Canada from 1940 to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Recent Canadian Art (formerly FAH416H1)

courses.name: Transregional East Asian Art

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth examination of the play of East Asian Art within and beyond East Asia.
cmCourseInfo.title: Transregional East Asian Art

courses.name: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Architecture (formerly FAH450H1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Course added: June 30, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth study of themes and problems in architecture in Renaissance and Baroque Europe.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Architecture (formerly FAH450H1)

courses.name: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol in this course, please contact contact Louise Kermode at the Art Department for details, email undergrad.arthistory@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship (formerly FAH455H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)

courses.name: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture (formerly FAH453H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to conservation, designed to give students a basic understanding of the field, its techniques, and its purposes. Sessions conducted by specialists in the Royal Ontario Museum conservation department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture (formerly FAH453H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor.

courses.name: Fashion, & Textiles: Culture & Consumption (formerly FAH459H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the history, meaning and consumption of Western European textiles (Late Antique - 18th century) and fashionable dress (18th - 21st centuries). Analysis and research will combine student seminars with the study of actual artefacts in the Textile & Costume Collection of the Royal Ontario Museum.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fashion, & Textiles: Culture & Consumption (formerly FAH459H1)

courses.name: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum (formerly FAH456H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical and practical engagement with the ROM's Canadian paintings, prints and drawing collections (18th-20th C). Through lectures, workshops, and seminars, we consider the collecting, interpretation, and display of images within the framework of documentary art and its various connotations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum (formerly FAH456H1)

courses.name: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth investigation of objects at the Royal Ontario Museum. Content will vary according to the museum department offering the course in any given semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

courses.name: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Impact of Historical Canadian Art on Contemporary Canadian Visual Culture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time changed: June 22, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused examination of special topics in any period of Mediterranean, European, North American, or Asian art and architecture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor
